message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hydropic villi with diffuse, circumferential trophoblastic proliferation are characteristic of a complete hydatidiform mole, which is caused by an abnormal fertilization event resulting in a diploid karyotype (46,XX or 46,XY). In this case, the karyotype will be 46,XX of paternal origin only, meaning that all chromosomes were contributed by the father and there is no maternal contribution.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This patient is presenting with a complete mole, which is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease. Complete moles result from fertilization of an egg without genetic material or fertilization by two sperm. In this case, there is likely fertilization of an egg by two sperm resulting in 46,XX of paternal origin only. Option A is incorrect because there is no maternal genetic material present in the mole. Option B is incorrect because 69,XXY is a triploid karyotype, and complete moles are diploid. Option D is incorrect because 69,XYY is also a triploid karyotype.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presented with an intrauterine mass and elevated β-hCG which suggests molar pregnancy. In molar pregnancies, all chromosomes come from the father and none from the mother, so the karyotype analysis would show 46,XX of paternal origin only (option C). The other options either include maternal chromosomes or non-disjunction of chromosomes during meiosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of hydropic villi with diffuse, circumferential trophoblastic proliferation suggests a complete hydatidiform mole, which is almost always fertilized by a single sperm. The karyotype of a complete mole is typically 46,XX, but it is of paternal origin only as the egg’s chromosomes have been lost or inactivated. Therefore, option (C) is the most likely karyotype.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound findings suggest a molar pregnancy, which is caused by the fertilization of an empty egg by a haploid sperm or by the fertilization of an egg by two sperm. This leads to a paternal genetic contribution only, resulting in the karyotype of 46,XX of paternal origin. Option A is impossible because it would require a maternal genetic contribution. Option B is unlikely and not correlated because it would result in a completely different karyotype. Option D is also not correlated because it would involve a different set of chromosomes.

We refer to the information on the different types of chromosomal aberrations. Hydatidiform mole is characterized by a benign neoplasm of the placenta, which develops as a result of abnormal fertilization where all of the genetic material is derived from the father. Karyotype analysis of the specimen will most likely show 46,XX of paternal origin only. Options (A), (B), and (D) are all incorrect because they do not involve the specific type of chromosomal aberration associated with hydatidiform mole.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient likely has a complete mole, which is an abnormal pregnancy. Complete moles are usually diploid with two sets of chromosomes but are entirely paternal in origin (no maternal genetic material). Therefore, the karyotype analysis is most likely to show 46,XX of paternal origin only.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This patient’s presentation and findings are consistent with a complete hydatidiform mole, which is caused by fertilization of an empty ovum by a haploid sperm, resulting in a completely paternal genome (46,XX of paternal origin). Options A, B, and D are all inconsistent with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a complete hydatidiform mole, which is caused by fertilization of an egg without a nucleus by a sperm that duplicates its chromosomes. This results in a complete set of paternal chromosomes and no maternal chromosomes, leading to a karyotype of 46,XX of paternal origin only. Option A is incorrect because a complete mole has no maternal chromosomes. Option B is incorrect because it describes Klinefelter syndrome, which is unrelated to this case. Option D is incorrect because it describes a non-disjunction event that is unrelated to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The histopathology findings suggest a complete hydatidiform mole, which is a result of a fertilized egg with no maternal genetic material. This means that the karyotype analysis is most likely to show 46,XX of paternal origin only. Options (B) and (D) involve paternal and maternal genetic material, and option (A) involves maternal genetic material only, which is not the case in a complete hydatidiform mole.
